narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much more about Cuba and the Cuban Revolution. The final paper allowed me to dive into a really interesting topic regarding the revolution, and it encouraged me to take what I had learned throughout the class and use it in a different context. It also inspired me to learn more about Cuba outside of the classroom/zoom room.

I thoroughly learned about Cuban history from an academic perspective. I also learned about how nuanced and complex history can be. I gained a thorough understanding of most time periods within Cuba. Lastly, I left with a plethora of readings that I can continue engaging with on my journey to learning about Cuba.

In high school, Cuba was a second of the curriculum, so it was amazing to actually learn about the complexities of Cuban history. Narratives on race, gender, foreign relations, and the revolution from the Afro-Cuban, the female, the refugee, the colonized perspective.

I developed critical thinking skills relating to history while also gaining a comprehensive base of knowledge on Cuban history and its unique place in relation to the topics of imperialism, colonization, and socialism.
I developed skills that helped me place historical events into context among countries and understand the cause/effect nature of certain historical events.
Writing skills, got comfortable with college seminar, and talking about history. Presentations were also very helpful and will definitely be using the things I learned completing them in the future.
Definitely the importance of periodicity in history, as someone who hasn't taken a history course before.
I learned how to ask questions about everything I read because historical narratives are more complex than they seem.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The amount of reading was very challenging in general even though the class was very engaging.  Also, the discussions were really productive. I feel like it can be more efficient if there is less reading assigned and more analysis.

Although the lectures were extremely interesting, they were hard to follow at times, and I think using a presentation or having more focused lectures could be helpful. I also found the readings to be fascinating, but they were often long and dense. This caused many students to skim and then not feel comfortable speaking about the readings because they had skimmed them. I think shorter readings with more casual articles mixed in would improve the quality of the discussions.

Readings towards the beginning of the course were extremely long and did not contribute much to our knowledge of the course material. I feel that student presentations were not the best use of class time since presentation covered readings that class members did on their own time. I think that time could have been spent engaging more with Cuban culture throughout the time periods since this is the one component that I felt the course could have contained more of. While I do have many critiques, this course was a robust introduction to Cuban history from an academic perspective and left me with many more questions and resources to answer these questions for myself.

Could have given more feedback consistently throughout the semester because I didn't know how I was doing until the end, but other than that a great course! The readings and lectures were powerful, and we had great discussions
The course was amazing and Professor Eller was engaging despite the drawbacks of COVID.

Professor Eller is extremely knowledgable about the subject, and her enthusiasm is clearly evident throughout class. The one weakness I would say this class has is a pretty overwhelming amount of reading, especially for a first year seminar.
More feedback from the professor throughout the semester, we received none.
Readings very repetitive and monotonous. Professor seller is very nice and brings up exciting topics that are related and unrelated to the course which keeps it engaging.
Loved the syllabus! The readings were sometimes a little too dense.

One major weakness in the course is that was difficult to gauge whether my writing was improving over the course of the semester due to the fact that we received very little feedback.  A strength of the course was the largely interesting reading material which contributed to productive and lively discussion during class. The material the professor would speak of in class to us was fascinating, but on days where there were no students presenting it sometimes felt more like a lecture. Having guiding discussion questions, I felt, really contributed to class engagement.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Our weekly responses were flexible in deadlines. I am grateful for this and felt that it was well in accordance with the times we are living in.
Zoom fatigue is to be expected, and I appreciated how our professor was very understanding if we were all a little tired out. Kept us engaged with presentations, art, and music
Virtual seminars worked very well, i felt connected to my classmates and Professor Eller.
The discussion format was effective but I think the response and discussion board posts could have been better included in class.
Zoom format went well. Breaks wouldve been nice. Breakout rooms are very boring and didnt find them very helpful especially if some of the few of us didnt do the reading .
The discussion posts were a great idea, I would improve upon this by enabling students to comment on others' posts

Sometimes the repetitive use of breakout rooms felt unnecessary to me, even though sometimes they actually contributed to a more varied discussion seeing as different groups would focus on different aspects of the day's subject. My suggestion is to decrease the use of breakout rooms, but not delete them altogether.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone looking for a hearty start at looking into Cuban history. There are many many sources that you will grapple with throughout this course and they covered a wide variety of perspectives and types of sources. The course is very engaging!

Yes!! Even if you have no connection to this class, take it! It helps fill in what was erased in our Eurocentric high school curriculum, you learn more about race, sexuality, gender, the Cold War, the Special Period, emigration, etc. from perspectives that are often dismissed
Yes, it was an informative and thought-provoking course that I feel anyone would benefit from taking.
Yes! If you're willing to put in the work you will gain so much from this course
Yes! I love this class. I was very  anxious about college work before coming to Yale and this really helped me adjust.
Yes! This class was extremely engaging and I would recommend it to anyone interested in the various praxes theories of gender, race, and nationalism as it pertains to the Caribbean

I would recommend this course to another student if they wanted to learn about a history not often covered in schools in the West. This course gave me access to a wealth of historical material that I had no idea of, and I got to discuss it with people who actively wanted to engage with the material and its connections to history as a whole.
